awd_titl_txt: Engineering Atomically Precise Nanochannels Using Layered 2D Sheets to Enable Chemical Separation Membranes with Exceptional Permeance and Size-Selectivity
awd_abstract_narration:
The separation of air into its components, oxygen, nitrogen, carbon dioxide, water vapor, and other trace gases such as helium, is a billion dollar industry. Examples include: use of purified nitrogen in high performance tires and infusion into specialty coffee; use of purified oxygen for healthcare and the launch space shuttles; use of helium for balloons. Separation of any mixture requires both energy and a strategy to isolate one component.  Size selective membranes provide one such strategy, allowing molecules to permeate through internal channels at rates that are dictated by their ability to fit within a membrane channel, their diffusivity, and the strength by which they interact with the surface.  Decreasing this surface interaction increases permeation, which translates to an increased production rate at lower energy consumption.  One candidate for frictionless transport are membrane channels comprised of carbon atoms, such as cylindrical carbon nanotubes or stacked planar graphene sheets.  As weak surface interactions provide little impediment to flow, the permeation of water through carbon nanotubes has been experimentally shown to be 1000 times greater than that predicted from classical models. Yet, homogenous channels of closely packed carbon nanotubes have been difficult to synthesize in large quantities.  Propped graphene sheets show more promise for large scale synthesis, but are currently derived from graphite via a highly oxidative delamination process, which imparts significant residual oxygen atoms that invalidate frictionless transport. This project will utilize a bottoms-up nonoxidative approach to create propped graphene membranes with controlled channels optimized for size selective transport of small molecules, such as oxygen, nitrogen, hydrogen, helium, and water.

This project will use molecular spacers as proppants to synthesize controlled nanochannels between pristine unoxidized parallel graphene sheets. Robust chemistries will be developed for precisely fabricating nanochannels with sub-nanometer gaps that range from 2-8 Angstroms to impart size selectivity. Candidate spacer molecules include para substituted benzene derivatives, functional groups grafted via [2+2] cycloaddition, and non-covalently adsorbed planar and non-planar aromatic hydrocarbons. Both isolated bilayer channels and multilayered laminate membranes will be fabricated. The isolated channels will afford fundamental surface science measurements of structure and properties whereas the multilayered membranes will enable macroscopic measurements of transport to validate the theoretical prediction of frictionless, ultrahigh permeance transport. Microstructural characterization data, in conjunction with transport measurements, will guide design of increasingly effective membrane materials. Both graduate and undergraduate students will perform laboratory research for this project, with an effort to target underrepresented groups. The research will inform interactive lessons targeted at high school level students, accompanied by dissemination of training videos to teachers.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
This project used experiments and computer simulations to investigate new materials for filtering and chemical separations applications, for example for water reclamation, air purification, fuel processing, and chemical production. New materials are needed for these applications that can improve energy efficiency, decrease cost, and increase throughput. At the same time, new materials are also needed that enable higher fidelity separations (for example, higher purities or better purification or separation between similar components).

The materials that were investigated were based on laminates or stacks of two-dimensional sheets based on graphene and graphene oxide. When these atomically thin sheets are stacked, molecules and ions can flow through and be confined in the spaces between the sheets. Chemicals can be separated according to the size of the gap between the sheets. For example, when the gap is about 0.7 nanometers (or 0.7 billionths of a meter) large, water molecules can flow through the confined space but larger sodium and chlorine ions cannot (for potential water desalination and reclamation applications).

At the project onset, it had already been discovered by others in the research community that laminates of graphene oxide are capable of purifying water. The first part of this research project conducted experiments to learn the fundamental pathways by which water flows through graphene oxide laminates. The project’s main conclusion was that the pathway for water transport does not follow a circuitous pathway around individual sheets but rather is affected by a combination of pinhole defects which permit flow through the sheets and voids which enable long range transport without interacting with the sheets (the latter of which is more prevalent with increasing membrane thickness). These pathways are illustrated in one of the associated images.

The second part of this research project used simulations to explore a promising new type of laminate comprised of unoxidized graphene sheets. Unoxidized graphene is smoother than graphene oxide and has been predicted to allow the exceptionally fast and nearly frictionless flow of molecules (important for improving energy efficiency, decreasing cost, and increasing throughput). However, unoxidized graphene sheets will collapse on each other leaving no measurable gap. To overcome this problem, this project investigated a molecular spacer approach to keep the sheets apart. These investigations were conducted using molecule dynamics simulations, which enable the behaviors of materials to be analyzed before they are synthesized experimentally. Simulations showed that grafting phenyl groups to the graphene sheets prevents the collapse of the laminates and opens a 0.7 nanometer gap that enables water desalination. A snapshot of one of the simulations is shown in one of the associated images. The red and white molecules are water; the purple and green are sodium and chlorine ions; the grey is carbon; and, the two layers of carbon with the label membrane are the laminate performing the water desalination. The sodium and chlorine ions are unable to permeate through the nanochannel defined by the two layers of unoxidized graphene sheets.

This work has provided insights into new, promising materials systems for next-generation chemical separation applications. Future work will evaluate the experimental synthesis of membrane materials based on unoxidized graphene sheets with molecular spacers.

The researchers in this project also conducted outreach in parallel with the scientific effort. Outreach activities included: mentoring a team of undergraduate students for their year-long senior design project on water purification (see associated image of team presenting their work); volunteering at the University of Wisconsin-Madison Engineering Expo and the Wisconsin Science Festival for the public; and the creation of an educational presentation on YouTube entitled “Graphene-Based Nanomembranes: Next-Generation Water Filtration Materials”. Undergraduate students, graduate students, and post-doctoral researchers were trained on a plethora of new skills, techniques, and scientific instrumentation. Finally, the graphene oxide portion of this research has been disseminated to the scientific community via a research paper in the journal ACS Nano and via multiple research presentations at scientific conferences and university seminars. An anticipated journal manuscript is still in preparation on the graphene / molecular spacer research.


Last Modified: 02/10/2022
Modified by: Michael Arnold

    Undergraduate Researchers
  • Possible water transport pathways through layered membranes of graphene oxide. Our experiments indicate a combination of pathways (B) and (C) are prevalent. Light grey-blue dashed ovals denote pinholes in B.
    Vivek Saraswat
    Copyrighted
    Michael Arnold
    Graphene oxide membrane pathways
